results.headline: The Football Formula: Take One Hero, Add Emotion, Watch Him Overcome

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Express

results.summary_short: “The Express” is an honorable example of a tried-and-true formula, aimed at a large cross-section of the moviegoing public: people who love football and hate racism.

results.headline: Fleeing a Dying Civilization, Toward Hope and Sunlight

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of City of Ember

results.summary_short: At moments “City of Ember” suggests a mild satire of end-of-days ideology.

results.headline: In Burkina Faso, Rebellion Stirs

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Delwende

results.summary_short: In “Delwende” the African filmmaker S. Pierre Yameogo tackles social injustice in present-day Burkina Faso with grace, economy and exquisitely controlled anger.

results.headline: Guns N’ Poses: Thugs, Drugs and Style in Shady London

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of RocknRolla

results.summary_short: Guy Ritchie reshuffles a worn-out deck in “RocknRolla,” a return to the shady stylings that characterized his earlier flicks.

results.headline: Comic Right-Wing Broadside (Very Broad)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of An American Carol

results.summary_short: Cheap shots and mean spirits abound in “An American Carol,” a lazy satire of the radical left.

results.headline: Stealing Glances

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Pleasure of Being Robbed

results.summary_short: The initial glimmer of hope “The Pleasure of Being Robbed” inspires with regard to the indie offshoot genre of mumblecore quickly dies.

results.headline: Out of Rehab, Wreaking Havoc

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rachel Getting Married

results.summary_short: The wonderful thing about “Rachel Getting Married” is how expansive it seems, in spite of the limits of its scope and the modesty of its ambitions.

results.headline: For Muddled Youth, Music to Live By

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nick & Norah's Infinite Playlist

results.summary_short: As thin as an iPod Nano, as full of adolescent self-display as a Facebook page, “Nick & Norah’s Infinite Playlist” strives to capture what it’s like to be young right now.

results.headline: A Guide to Burning Your Bridges
results.display_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of How to Lose Friends & Alienate People

results.summary_short: The crushingly unfunny and slopped-together “How to Lose Friends & Alienate People” has neither the ambition nor the intelligence to do justice to its source material.

results.headline: Waiting to Inhale on the Lost Coast

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Humboldt County

results.summary_short: So much pot is smoked in the agreeable drama “Humboldt County” that you may come away from it with a contact high.

results.headline: Splatter Matters

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tokyo Gore Police

results.summary_short: Propelled by geysers of blood and tidal waves of neuroses, “Tokyo Gore Police” plumbs wounds both cultural and physical to deliver splatterific social satire.

results.headline: An Everyman Inventor Fights the Detroit Goliaths

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Flash of Genius

results.summary_short: “Flash of Genius” is a doggedly workmanlike variation of an old story: the lone crusader doing battle with the big bad establishment.

results.headline: Comedy With a Mission

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Allah Made Me Funny

results.summary_short: “Allah Made Me Funny” looks at comedians who, through humor, aim to bring mainstream awareness to the position of Muslims within modern Western society.

results.headline: Barking With Bite

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beverly Hills Chihuahua

results.summary_short: “Beverly Hills Chihuahua” approaches but never quite achieves a truly spectacular level of absurdity.

results.headline: Characters Who Learn to See by Falling Into a World Without Sight

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blindness

results.summary_short: “Blindness” is not a great film. But it is, nonetheless, full of examples of what good filmmaking looks like.

results.headline: Catching the Heartbeat and Fragmented Poetry of the Delta

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ballast

results.summary_short: “Ballast” is a serious achievement and a welcome sign of a newly invigorated American independent cinema.

results.headline: Believers, Skeptics and a Pool of Sitting Ducks

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Religulous

results.summary_short: “Religulous” is a film that aims for laughs, not a scientific survey of the roots of faith.

results.headline: Juggling Spouse and Parent, Painfully

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Smother

results.summary_short: “Smother,” starring Diane Keaton and Dax Shepard, is a shrill would-be comedy that isn’t easy to watch.

results.headline: Putting Out House Fires, Reigniting Passions

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fireproof

results.summary_short: “Fireproof” is a decent attempt to combine faith and storytelling that will certainly register with its target audience.

results.headline: On the Run From Terrorists and a Disembodied Voice

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Eagle Eye

results.summary_short: “Eagle Eye” is the latest evidence that sometimes, at the movies, more is less.
